conbody.p: On first boot, the VM generates a hostname in the form stackato-xxxx.local. This hostname is displayed on the hypervisor console. It receives its IP address via DHCP and broadcasts the generated hostname on the local subnet via multicast DNS.
You will use this hostname to open the Management Console in a browser or to connect to the CLI client.
conbody.note: The default password for the system user is hcf. This password is changed automatically when you set up the first administrative user in the Management Console. Once you set up the primary administrator account, use that account password to log in from the command line.

section.title: NAT vs. Bridged Networking
section.p: The VMware and VirtualBox start virtual machines with NAT networking enabled by default.
If you use VirtualBox to run the VM, configure Bridged networking before starting the VM. To run in NAT mode, configure port forwarding as described in the VirtualBox documentation.

note.p: Bridged networking exposes the VM to your local network through the hypervisor host system. This makes it easier to connect to servers running on other hosts. However, this should be done only on trusted networks.
NAT networking exposes the VM only to the host system (unless routing through the host is configured). This configuration is recommended if you are operating on an untrusted network.

Multiple hosts broadcasting the same name via mDNS on the same network can cause confusion and network problems. If you plan on running multiple Stackato micro clouds on one network, follow these guidelines:

ul.li: Ensure that the MAC address of each virtual machine is unique

If the hostname is not unique, do one of the following:
Change the hostname
Use NAT networking
Configure DNS manually

section.title: DNS vs. mDNS
section.p: By default, the VM broadcasts its generated hostname via multicast DNS. This mDNS/DNS-SD broadcast address (for example, stackato-xxxx.local) is intended for micro clouds running on a local machine or subnet. To use the VM on a remote subnet, the server may need one or more of the following:

li.b: A wildcard DNS A or CNAME record
A hostname that works with xip.io

section.p: For instructions on setting up the VM in these situations, see the Detailed Configuration.

note.p: Windows does not properly support mDNS hostname resolution. You will need to use the xip.io service, update the Windows hosts file, or create a DNS record in order to target the API endpoint, push applications, and resolve the deployed applications.
